"dmoz/Society/Crime/Prevention", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Sikhism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Sikhism", "wgt": 83}, {"uri": "news/Politics", {"uri": "8110259389", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "20:50:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T20:50:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T20:49:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2927128-3-indian-nationals-arrested-in-killing-of-alleged-khalistan-advocate", "title": "3 Indian Nationals Arrested in Killing of Alleged Khalistan Advocate | Law-Order", "body": "Canadian police arrested three Indian nationals for the 2023 murder of Khalistan separatist Nijjar. Investigations suggest ties to the Indian government, which Canada raised concerns about last year. The suspects, identified as Brar, Karanpreet Singh, and Kamalpreet Singh, face murder and conspiracy charges. The investigation also looks into possible connections to other murders in Canada. India has denied allegations of involvement in Nijjar's killing, citing concerns about separatism and extremism in Canada. The arrests have strained relations between the two countries, leading Canada to downsize its diplomatic presence in India.\n\nCanadian police have arrested three Indian nationals believed by investigators to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year, police said.\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the ''potential'' involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as ''absurd'' and ''motivated.'' Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner David Teboul said that three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar.\n\nAddressing a press conference on Friday, he said that in addition to the murder case, separate investigations are looking into possible connections to the Government of India, The Toronto Star newspaper reported.\n\nTeboul stressed that the murder remains ''very much under active investigation,'' CTV News reported.\n\n''There are separate and distinct investigations ongoing into these matters, certainly not limited to the involvement of the people arrested today, and these efforts include investigating connections to the government of India,'' he was quoted as saying by the news channel.\n\nDuring the press conference, Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, who leads the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team, said that the suspects ''were not known to the police'' before the investigation into Nijjar's death.\n\nMooker identified the suspects as Karan Brar, Karanpreet Singh and Kamalpreet Singh, all men in their 20s, who were arrested on Friday in Edmonton.\n\nMooker said all three are Indian nationals and have been living as non-permanent residents in Canada for the last three to five years.\n\nHe said coordination with India has been ''challenging and rather difficult for the last several years''.\n\nMooker said that his investigation has relied on the Sikh community's support.\n\n''We would not be at this point without the bravery and courage of the Sikh community coming forward with information for this investigation,'' he said, adding that he believes they will continue to come forward for any future investigations, according to the report.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count of first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nCiting sources, a report in Global News said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to murder on May 1, 2023, in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nTalking to reporters, Canada's Public Safety Minister Dominic Leblanc declined to confirm the Indian government connection, saying such questions are best addressed by the RCMP.\n\n''I have full confidence in the security apparatus of the government of Canada and the work of the RCMP, and the work that the (Canadian) Security Intelligence Service does,'' Leblanc said.\n\n''I think the police operation that you see ongoing today confirms that the RCMP take these matters extremely seriously. But questions with respect to particular links or non-links are properly put to the RCMP,'' he added.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023, and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a ''problem'' and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n''PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,'' External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n''This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,'' he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-Khalistan slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n''It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,'' Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its ''core issue'' with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended the issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", {"uri": "8111462453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "18:48:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T18:48:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T18:47:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/india/india-responds-after-3-indian-nationals-arrested-in-canada-in-terrorist-hardeep-singh-nijjars-killing-2523903", "title": "India responds after 3 Indian nationals arrested in Canada in terrorist Hardeep Singh Nijjar's killing", "body": "New Delhi: The Indian government reacted hours after the Canadian Police arrested three Indians nationals believed by investigators to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year.\n\n\"We have been informed by the Canadian officials about the arrest of three Indian nationals, residing in Canada, in connection with shooting of a Canadian citizen Hardeep Singh Nijjar. We hope to get regular updates from the concerned Canadian authorities regarding the arrested Indian nationals,\" Indian High Commissioner to Canada Sanjay Verma said in a statement .\n\n\"I understand that the arrests have been made as a result of investigations conducted by the relevant Canadian law enforcement agencies. This issue is internal to Canada and therefore we have no comments to offer in this regard,\" he added.\n\n\"As stated time and again, it is not the policy of the Government of India to interfere in the internal affairs of other countries. We are always ready to work with partner countries in solving crimes, provided specific and relevant evidence is shared with us,\" statement reads further.\n\nIt is pertinent to mention that the ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner David Teboul said that three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar.\n\nAddressing a press conference on Friday, he said that in addition to the murder case, separate investigations are looking into possible connections to the Government of India, The Toronto Star newspaper reported.\n\nTeboul stressed that the murder remains \"very much under active investigation,\" CTV News reported.\n\n\"There are separate and distinct investigations ongoing into these matters, certainly not limited to the involvement of the people arrested today, and these efforts include investigating connections to the government of India,\" he was quoted as saying by the news channel.\n\nDuring the press conference, Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, who leads the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team, said that the suspects \"were not known to the police\" before the investigation into Nijjar's death.\n\nMooker identified the suspects as Karan Brar, Karanpreet Singh and Kamalpreet Singh, all men in their 20s, who were arrested on Friday in Edmonton.\n\nMooker said all three are Indian nationals and have been living as non-permanent residents in Canada for the last three to five years.\n\nHe said coordination with India has been \"challenging and rather difficult for the last several years\".\n\nMooker said that his investigation has relied on the Sikh community's support.\n\n\"We would not be at this point without the bravery and courage of the Sikh community coming forward with information for this investigation,\" he said, adding that he believes they will continue to come forward for any future investigations, according to the report.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count of first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nCiting sources, a report in Global News said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to murder on May 1, 2023, in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nTalking to reporters, Canada's Public Safety Minister Dominic Leblanc declined to confirm the Indian government connection, saying such questions are best addressed by the RCMP.\n\n\"I have full confidence in the security apparatus of the government of Canada and the work of the RCMP, and the work that the (Canadian) Security Intelligence Service does,\" Leblanc said.\n\n\"I think the police operation that you see ongoing today confirms that the RCMP take these matters extremely seriously. But questions with respect to particular links or non-links are properly put to the RCMP,\" he added.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023, and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a \"problem\" and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n\"PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,\" External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n\"This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,\" he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-Khalistan slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n\"It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,\" Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its \"core issue\" with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended the issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. addition to the murder case, separate investigations are looking into possible connections to the Government of India, The Toronto Star newspaper reported.\n\nTeboul stressed that the murder remains \"very much under active investigation,\" CTV News reported.\n\n\"There are separate and distinct investigations ongoing into these matters, certainly not limited to the involvement of the people has relied on the Sikh community's support.\n\n\"We would not be at this point without the bravery and courage of the Sikh community coming forward with information for this investigation,\" he said, adding that he believes they will continue to come forward for any future investigations, according to the report.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count of first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nCiting sources, a report in Global News said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\"\n\nAccording to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to murder on May 1, 2023, in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nTalking to reporters, Canada's Public Safety Minister Dominic Leblanc declined to confirm the Indian government connection, saying such questions are best addressed by the RCMP.\n\n\"I have full confidence in the security apparatus of the government of Canada and the work of the RCMP, and the work that the (Canadian) Security Intelligence Service does,\" Leblanc said.\n\n\"I think the police operation that you see ongoing today confirms that the RCMP take these matters extremely seriously. But questions with respect to particular links or non-links are properly put to the RCMP,\" he added.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023, and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a \"problem\" and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n\"PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,\" External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n\"This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,\" he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-Khalistan slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n\"It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,\" Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its \"core issue\" with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended the issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. {"uri": "8110268622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "21:01:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T21:01:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T21:00:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/3-indian-nationals-arrested-in-killing-of-khalistan-separatist-nijjar-canadian-police-4534982", "title": "3 Indian nationals arrested in killing of Khalistan separatist Nijjar: Canadian police", "body": "Ottawa, May 4 (PTI) Canadian police have arrested three Indian nationals believed by investigators to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year, police said.\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner David Teboul said that three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar.\n\nAddressing a press conference on Friday, he said that in addition to the murder case, separate investigations are looking into possible connections to the Government of India, The Toronto Star newspaper reported.\n\nTeboul stressed that the murder remains \"very much under active investigation,\" CTV News reported.\n\n\"There are separate and distinct investigations ongoing into these matters, certainly not limited to the involvement of the people arrested today, and these efforts include investigating connections to the government of India,\" he was quoted as saying by the news channel.\n\nDuring the press conference, Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, who leads the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team, said that the suspects \"were not known to the police\" before the investigation into Nijjar's death.\n\nMooker identified the suspects as Karan Brar, Karanpreet Singh and Kamalpreet Singh, all men in their 20s, who were arrested on Friday in Edmonton.\n\nMooker said all three are Indian nationals and have been living as non-permanent residents in Canada for the last three to five years.\n\nHe said coordination with India has been \"challenging and rather difficult for the last several years\".\n\nMooker said that his investigation has relied on the Sikh community's support.\n\n\"We would not be at this point without the bravery and courage of the Sikh community coming forward with information for this investigation,\" he said, adding that he believes they will continue to come forward for any future investigations, according to the report.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count of first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nCiting sources, a report in Global News said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to murder on May 1, 2023, in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nTalking to reporters, Canada's Public Safety Minister Dominic Leblanc declined to confirm the Indian government connection, saying such questions are best addressed by the RCMP.\n\n\"I have full confidence in the security apparatus of the government of Canada and the work of the RCMP, and the work that the (Canadian) Security Intelligence Service does,\" Leblanc said.\n\n\"I think the police operation that you see ongoing today confirms that the RCMP take these matters extremely seriously. But questions with respect to particular links or non-links are properly put to the RCMP,\" he added.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023, and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a \"problem\" and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n\"PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,\" External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n\"This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,\" he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-Khalistan slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n\"It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,\" Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its \"core issue\" with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended the issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later. Nijjar, 45, was shot dead in June outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population. A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nPolice said the matter was still under investigation and other probes were being carried out. The three men were named as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22. \"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, a police superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labeled Nijjar a \"terrorist\". Last week the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with U.S. law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details. The trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday without incident, police said. The three are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.\n\nTrudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder of Nijjar. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as \"absurd.\" Canada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Last November, U.S. authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the U.S. and {"uri": "8110127083", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:37:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:37:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:36:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2927089-indian-nationals-arrested-in-murder-of-khalistan-separatist-nijjar-in-canada", "title": "Indian Nationals Arrested in Murder of Khalistan Separatist Nijjar in Canada | Law-Order", "body": "Three Indian nationals have been arrested in Canada for allegedly killing Khalistani separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar. The arrests follow Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's accusations of possible Indian involvement in Nijjar's death. India has denied the charges, citing political support for separatism in Canada. The suspects, identified as Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh, and Karan Brar, are charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder. The hit squad allegedly had different roles on the day of Nijjar's killing. The arrests and investigation center around potential links to other murders, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy. The arrests have put further strain on India-Canada relations, with India rejecting Trudeau's comments and summoning the Canadian deputy high commissioner.\n\nCanadian police on Friday arrested three Indian nationals believed by investigators to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year, according to media reports.\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the ''potential'' involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as ''absurd'' and ''motivated.'' Three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar, CTV News quoted a senior government source as saying.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to commit murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nA report in Global News identified the suspects as Indians nationals.\n\n''The RCMP took the Indian nationals into custody on Friday morning,\" almost a year after Nijjar was gunned down, the report said.\n\nCiting sources, it said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to commit murder on May 1, 2023 in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023 and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nThe men were arrested Friday during police operations in at least two provinces, the report said.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police are expected to announce the arrests and share some details of their investigation later Friday, CTV News reported, quoting a senior government source.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a ''problem'' and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n''PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,'' External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n''This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,'' he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-'Khalistan' slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n''It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,'' Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its ''core issue'' with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", The three men were named as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, a police superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labeled Nijjar a terrorist.\n\nLast week the Biden administration expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with U.S. law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday without incident, police said. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Last November, U.S. authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the U.S. and {"uri": "8110544562", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "03:23:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T03:23:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T03:23:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://bdnews24.com/world/e7d27336446a", "title": "Canada police charge three with murder of Sikh leader Nijjar, probe India link", "body": "Bhupinder Singh speaks at a press conference held at Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara, site of the 2023 murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar, in Surrey, British Columbia, Canada May 3, 2024. REUTERS\n\nCanadian police on Friday arrested and charged three Indian men with the murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar last year and said they were probing whether the men had ties to the Indian government.\n\nNijjar, 45, was shot dead in June outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population. A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police named the three men as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, an RCMP superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nThe Indian mission in Ottawa did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labelled Nijjar a \"terrorist\".\n\nLast week the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details, and suggested more detentions might be coming.\n\n\"This investigation does not end here. We are aware that others may have played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to finding and arresting each one of these individuals,\" said assistant RCMP commissioner David Teboul.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday, police said. They are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.\n\nTrudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\n\"We welcome the arrests but this does lead to a lot more questions,\" said Balpreet Singh, legal counsel and spokesperson for the Canada-based World Sikh Organization advocacy group.\n\n\"Those who have been arrested are part of a hit squad but it's clear that they were directed,\" he said by phone.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Last November, US authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder on US soil of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the US and Canada.\n\n\"While today's action ... is a step forward, it only scratches the surface,\" Pannun said in a statement, calling for action to \"dismantle the networks that enable and perpetuate such {"uri": "8110834105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "08:33:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T08:33:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T08:32:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2927338-indian-men-arrested-in-canada-for-murder-of-sikh-activist", "title": "Indian Men Arrested in Canada for Murder of Sikh Activist | Law-Order", "body": "Canadian authorities have arrested three Indian nationals in connection with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar. The investigation is ongoing, and more arrests are expected. Police are investigating the possible involvement of the Indian government in the murder. The three suspects are believed to be members of a hit squad tasked with killing Nijjar. The arrests have strained relations between India and Canada, which has denied involvement in the killing. India has summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner to protest the raising of pro-Khalistan slogans at an event attended by Prime Minister Trudeau.\n\nCanadian authorities, who arrested three Indian nationals in connection with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Canada, have said that their investigation has not concluded and ''others'' who played a role in the homicide would also be arrested. Karan Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton have been charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) on Friday said they are investigating if the Indian government was involved in the killing of Nijjar, a Canadian citizen. The three are believed to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Nijjar, 45, outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023. \"The investigation does not end here. We are aware that there are others out there that played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to identifying and arresting each one of them,\" Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, Officer in Charge of the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team (IHIT) said.\n\nThe three men were arrested for the murder of Nijjar Friday morning by IHIT investigators, with the assistance of members from the British Columbia and Alberta Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) and the Edmonton Police Service.\n\nRoyal Canadian Mounted Police Assistant Commissioner David Teboul said they are not able to make any comments about the nature of the evidence collected by police nor \"can we speak about the motive\" behind Nijjar's murder.\n\nWhen asked whether there are any Indian ''sleeper agents'' in Canada, Teboul said he could not say more because the issue is ''very much at the centre of evidence and ongoing investigations'', CBC News reported.\n\nAsked whether the public should consider the men to have been ''guns for hire,'' police said more information would come out in court, it said.\n\n\"However, understanding this situation has attracted considerable and very broad public interest, I will say this matter is still very much under active investigation. I will underscore that today's announcements are not a complete account of the investigative work currently underway. ''There are separate and distinct investigations ongoing into these matters, certainly not limited to the involvement of the people arrested today, and these efforts include investigating connections to the Government of India.\" The ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the ''potential'' involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as ''absurd'' and ''motivated.'' During the press conference, Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, who leads the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team, said, ''IHIT is releasing photos of the accused men in hopes of furthering its investigation. Anyone who may have seen these individuals, in or around Surrey, in the weeks leading up to the homicide, or anyone with information about the homicide is asked to contact IHIT.\n\nHe said that the suspects ''were not known to the police'' before the investigation into Nijjar's death, according to reports.\n\nMooker said all three are Indian nationals and have been living as non-permanent residents in Canada for the last three to five years.\n\nHe said coordination with India has been ''challenging and rather difficult for the last several years''.\n\nMooker said that his investigation has relied on the Sikh community's support.\n\n''We would not be at this point without the bravery and courage of the Sikh community coming forward with information for this investigation,'' he said, adding that he believes they will continue to come forward for any future investigations, according to the report.\n\nCiting sources, a report in Global News said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to murder on May 1, 2023, in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nTalking to reporters, Canada's Public Safety Minister Dominic Leblanc declined to confirm the Indian government connection, saying such questions are best addressed by the RCMP.\n\n''I have full confidence in the security apparatus of the government of Canada and the work of the RCMP, and the work that the (Canadian) Security Intelligence Service does,'' Leblanc said.\n\n''I think the police operation that you see ongoing today confirms that the RCMP take these matters extremely seriously. But questions with respect to particular links or non-links are properly put to the RCMP,'' he added.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023, and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nIndia on Monday summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-Khalistan slogans at the event in the presence of Prime Minister Trudeau and several other leaders.\n\nNijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its ''core issue'' with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended the issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police named the three men as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, an RCMP superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nAlso read: Trudeau aide: India is cooperating with Canada amid tensions over Nijjar's killing\n\nThe Indian mission in Ottawa did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labelled Nijjar a \"terrorist\".\n\nLast week the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with U.S. law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details, and suggested more detentions might be coming.\n\n\"This investigation does not end here. We are aware that others may have played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to finding and arresting each one of these individuals,\" said assistant RCMP commissioner David Teboul.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday, police said. They are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.\n\nTrudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\n\"We welcome the arrests but this does lead to a lot more questions,\" said Balpreet Singh, legal counsel and spokesperson for the Canada-based World Sikh Organization advocacy group.\n\n\"Those who have been arrested are part of a hit squad but it's clear that they were directed,\" he said by phone. Canada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Last November, U.S. authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder on U.S. soil of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the U.S. and Canada.\n\n\"While today's action is a step forward, it only scratches the surface,\" Pannun said in a statement, calling for action to \"dismantle the networks that enable and perpetuate such {"uri": "8110262828", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "20:54:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T20:54:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T20:53:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://sg.news.yahoo.com/canadian-police-made-arrests-case-164137676.html", "title": "Canada police charge three with murder of Sikh leader Nijjar, probe India link", "body": "Press conference on the 2023 murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar, at B.C. RCMP headquarters in Surrey, British Columbia\n\nOTTAWA (Reuters) -Canadian police on Friday arrested and charged three Indian men with the murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar last year and said they were probing whether the men had ties to the Indian government.\n\nNijjar, 45, was shot dead in June outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population. A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nPolice said the matter was still under investigation and other probes were being carried out. The three men were named as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, a police superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labeled Nijjar a \"terrorist\".\n\nLast week the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with U.S. law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday without incident, police said. The three are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.\n\nTrudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder of Nijjar. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as \"absurd.\"\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Last November, U.S. authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the U.S. and Canada.\n\n(Reporting by David Ljunggren and Ismail Shakil;Editing by Chizu Nomiyama, Josie Kao and Deepa Babington)", "source": {"uri": "sg.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo {"uri": "8110132935", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:43:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:43:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:42:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2927095-canadian-police-arrest-3-suspects-in-killing-of-khalistan-separatist-nijjar-media-reports", "title": "Canadian police arrest 3 suspects in killing of Khalistan separatist Nijjar: Media reports | Law-Order", "body": "Canadian police on Friday arrested three Indian nationals believed by investigators to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year, according to media reports.\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the ''potential'' involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as ''absurd'' and ''motivated.'' Three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar, CTV News quoted a senior government source as saying.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to commit murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nA report in Global News identified the suspects as Indians nationals.\n\n''The RCMP took the Indian nationals into custody on Friday morning,\" almost a year after Nijjar was gunned down, the report said.\n\nCiting sources, it said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to commit murder on May 1, 2023 in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nTalking to reporters on Parliament Hill, Canada's public safety minister declined to confirm the Indian government connection on Friday, saying such questions are best addressed by the RCMP.\n\n''I have full confidence in the security apparatus of the government of Canada and the work of the RCMP, and the work that the (Canadian) Security Intelligence Service does,'' Public Safety Minister Dominic Leblanc said.\n\n''I think the police operation that you see ongoing today confirms that the RCMP take these matters extremely seriously. But questions with respect to particular links or non-links are properly put to the RCMP,'' he added.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023 and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nThe men were arrested Friday during police operations in at least two provinces, the report said.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police are expected to announce the arrests and share some details of their investigation later Friday, CTV News reported, quoting a senior government source.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a ''problem'' and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n''PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,'' External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n''This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,'' he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-'Khalistan' slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n''It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,'' Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its ''core issue'' with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", {"uri": "8110580435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "04:08:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T04:08:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T04:08:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2927219-three-indian-nationals-detained-in-canada-in-relation-to-nijjar-murder-others-suspected", "title": "Three Indian Nationals Detained in Canada in Relation to Nijjar Murder, Others Suspected | Law-Order", "body": "Three Indian nationals have been arrested in Canada for the murder of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar. The investigation is ongoing, and authorities believe others were involved. The suspects are part of an alleged hit squad allegedly tasked by the Indian government. The arrests have heightened tensions between India and Canada, as Canada has accused India of involvement, which India has denied. The police are also investigating possible links to other murders in Canada.\n\nCanadian authorities, who arrested three Indian nationals in connection with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Canada, said their investigation has not concluded and ''others'' played a role in the homicide.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals, residing in Edmonton have been charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\nThe three are believed by investigators to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Nijjar, 45, outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen. \"The investigation does not end here. We are aware that there are others out there that played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to identifying and arresting each one of them,\" Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, Officer in Charge of the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team (IHIT) said.\n\nThe three men were arrested for the murder of Nijjar Friday morning by IHIT investigators, with the assistance of members from the British Columbia and Alberta Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) and the Edmonton Police Service.\n\nRoyal Canadian Mounted Police Assistant Commissioner David Teboul said they are not able to make any comments about the nature of the evidence collected by police nor \"can we speak about the motive\" behind Nijjar's murder.\n\n\"However, understanding this situation has attracted considerable and very broad public interest, I will say this matter is still very much under active investigation. I will underscore that today's announcements are not a complete account of the investigative work currently underway. ''There are separate and distinct investigations ongoing into these matters, certainly not limited to the involvement of the people arrested today, and these efforts include investigating connections to the Government of India.\" The ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the ''potential'' involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as ''absurd'' and ''motivated.'' Teboul said that three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar.\n\nTeboul stressed that the murder remains ''very much under active investigation.'' During the press conference, Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, who leads the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team, said, ''IHIT is releasing photos of the accused men in hopes of furthering its investigation. Anyone who may have seen these individuals, in or around Surrey, in the weeks leading up to the homicide, or anyone with information about the homicide is asked to contact IHIT.\n\nHe said that the suspects ''were not known to the police'' before the investigation into Nijjar's death, according to reports.\n\nMooker said all three are Indian nationals and have been living as non-permanent residents in Canada for the last three to five years.\n\nHe said coordination with India has been ''challenging and rather difficult for the last several years''.\n\nMooker said that his investigation has relied on the Sikh community's support.\n\n''We would not be at this point without the bravery and courage of the Sikh community coming forward with information for this investigation,'' he said, adding that he believes they will continue to come forward for any future investigations, according to the report.\n\nCiting sources, a report in Global News said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to murder on May 1, 2023, in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nTalking to reporters, Canada's Public Safety Minister Dominic Leblanc declined to confirm the Indian government connection, saying such questions are best addressed by the RCMP.\n\n''I have full confidence in the security apparatus of the government of Canada and the work of the RCMP, and the work that the (Canadian) Security Intelligence Service does,'' Leblanc said.\n\n''I think the police operation that you see ongoing today confirms that the RCMP take these matters extremely seriously. But questions with respect to particular links or non-links are properly put to the RCMP,'' he added.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023, and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nIndia on Monday summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-Khalistan slogans at the event in the presence of Prime Minister Trudeau and several other leaders.\n\nNijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its ''core issue'' with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended the issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police named the three men as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, an RCMP superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nThe Indian mission in Ottawa did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labelled Nijjar a \"terrorist\".\n\nLast week, the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details, and suggested more detentions might be coming.\n\n\"This investigation does not end here. We are aware that others may have played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to finding and arresting each one of these individuals,\" said assistant RCMP commissioner David Teboul.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday, police said. They are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday 6 May 2024.\n\nTrudeau announced in September 2023 that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\n\"We welcome the arrests but this does lead to a lot more questions,\" said Balpreet Singh, legal counsel and spokesperson for the Canada-based World Sikh Organization advocacy group.\n\n\"Those who have been arrested are part of a hit squad but it's clear that they were directed,\" he said by phone.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Last November, US authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder on US soil of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the US and killing\n\nCanada is a \"rule-of-law country\" with a strong and independent justice system and a fundamental commitment to protect its citizens, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said, a day after three Indian nationals were charged with the murder of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar.\n\nNijjar, a Canadian citizen, was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton have been charged on Friday with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Trudeau said about the arrests on Saturday at a Toronto gala celebrating Sikh heritage and culture.\n\n\"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday,\" Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) quoted Trudeau as saying.\n\nHe said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing, adding: \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada.\" The ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of 45-year-old Nijjar, a Khalistan separatist.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India, which had designated Nijjar a \"terrorist.\" After three {"uri": "8111303280", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "16:03:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T16:03:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T15:59:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2024/05/05/2003817391", "title": "Canada police charge three with murder of Sikh leader - Taipei Times", "body": "Canadian police on Friday arrested and charged three Indian men with the murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar last year and said they were probing whether the men had ties to the Indian government.\n\nNijjar, 45, was shot dead in June last year outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population. A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) named the three suspects as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karan Brar, 22.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" RCMP Superintendent Mandeep Mooker told a televised news conference.\n\nThe Indian mission in Ottawa did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labeled Nijjar a \"terrorist.\"\n\nLast week, the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the US.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details, and suggested more detentions might be coming.\n\n\"This investigation does not end here. We are aware that others may have played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to finding and arresting each one of these individuals,\" RCMP Assistant Commissioner David Teboul said.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in Edmonton, Alberta, police said.\n\nThey are due to arrive in British Columbia by tomorrow.\n\nTrudeau in September last year announced that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\n\"We welcome the arrests, but this does lead to a lot more questions,\" said Balpreet Singh, legal counsel and spokesperson for the Canada-based World Sikh Organization advocacy group.\n\n\"Those who have been arrested are part of a hit squad, but it's clear that they were directed,\" he said by phone.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation.\n\nIn November last year, US authorities said that an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder on US soil of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the US and Canada.\n\n\"While today's action ... is a step forward, it only scratches the surface,\" Pannun said in a statement, calling for action to \"dismantle the networks that enable and perpetuate such crimes against Canadians on Canadian soil.\"", "source": {"uri": "taipeitimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Taipei Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8111850003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:19:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:19:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:18:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/canada-is-a-rule-of-law-country-trudeau-tells-sikh-community-day-after-arrest-of-three-indians-8878426.html", "title": "'Canada Is A Rule-Of-Law Country': Trudeau Tells Sikh Community Day After Arrest Of Three Indians In Nijjar Murder Case - News18", "body": "Trudeau's comments came during an event in Toronto which was celebrating Sikh heritage and culture.\n\nCanada is a \"rule-of-law country\" with a strong and independent justice system and a fundamental commitment to protect its citizens, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said, a day after three Indian nationals were charged with the murder of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar.\n\nNijjar, a Canadian citizen, was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton have been charged on Friday with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Trudeau said about the arrests on Saturday at a Toronto gala celebrating Sikh heritage and culture.\n\n\"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday,\" Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) quoted Trudeau as saying.\n\nHe said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing, adding: \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada.\" The ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of 45-year-old Nijjar, a Khalistan separatist.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India, which had designated Nijjar a \"terrorist.\" After three Indian nationals were arrested in connection with the murder, Police in Canada said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\nThe police suggested more arrests might be coming. Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner David Teboul, the force's commander for the Pacific region, said Friday that he wouldn't comment on the alleged links between the three men arrested and Indian officials but noted the force is \"investigating connections to the government of India.\" Meanwhile, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Saturday said what is happening in poll-bound Canada over the killing of Nijjar is mostly due to their internal politics and has nothing to do with India.\n\nHe said a section of pro-Khalistan people are using Canada's democracy, creating a lobby and have become a vote bank.\n\nThe ruling party in Canada has no majority in Parliament and some parties depend on pro-Khalistan leaders, he said.\n\n\"We have convinced them several times not to give visa, legitimacy or political space to such people which is causing problems for them (Canada), for us and also for our relationship,\" Jaishankar said.\n\nBut the Canadian government has not done anything, Jaishankar said, adding that India sought the extradition of 25 people, most of whom are pro-Khalistan, but they did not pay any heed.\n\n\"Canada did not give any proof. They do not share any evidence with us in certain cases, police agencies also do not cooperate with us. It is their political compulsion in Canada to blame India. As elections are coming in Canada, they indulge in vote bank politics,\" the minister said.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts":
