"sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.dailyexcelsior.com/this-is-important-because-canada-is-a-rule-of-law-country-pm-trudeau-to-arrest-of-3-indian-men-in-nijjar-murder-case/", "title": "'This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country': PM Trudeau to arrest of 3 Indian men in Nijjar murder case", "body": "Toronto, May 5: Canada is a \"rule-of-law country\" with a strong and independent justice system and a fundamental commitment to protect its citizens, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said, a day after three Indian nationals were charged with the murder of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar.\n\nNijjar, a Canadian citizen, was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton, were charged on May 3 with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Mr. Trudeau said about the arrests at a Toronto gala celebrating Sikh heritage and culture. \"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday,\" Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) quoted Mr. Trudeau as saying.\n\nHe said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing, adding: \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada.\"\n\nDiploamtic tussel\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Mr. Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of 45-year-old Nijjar, a Khalistan separatist. India has dismissed Mr. Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India, which had designated Nijjar a \"terrorist.\"\n\nAfter three Indian nationals were arrested in connection with the murder, Police in Canada said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\nThe police suggested more arrests might be coming. Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner David Teboul, the force's commander for the Pacific region, said Friday that he wouldn't comment on the alleged links between the three men arrested and Indian officials but noted the force is \"investigating connections to the government of India.\"\n\nMeanwhile, External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar on May 4 said what is happening in poll-bound Canada over the killing of Nijjar is mostly due to their internal politics and has nothing to do with India. He said a section of pro-Khalistan people are using Canada's democracy, creating a lobby and have become a vote bank.\n\nThe ruling party in Canada has no majority in Parliament and some parties depend on pro-Khalistan leaders, he said.\n\n\"We have convinced them several times not to give visa, legitimacy or political space to such people which is causing problems for them (Canada), for us and also for our relationship,\" Jaishankar said. But the Canadian government has not done anything, he said, adding that India sought the extradition of 25 people, most of whom are pro-Khalistan, but they did not pay any heed.\n\n\"Canada did not give any proof. They do not share any evidence with us in certain cases, police agencies also do not cooperate with us. It is their political compulsion in Canada to blame India. As elections are coming in Canada, they indulge in vote bank politics,\" the minister said. The Statesman", "body": "The police have charged them with first-degree murder and conspiracy in the Nijjar case.\n\nCanadian police have arrested three Indian nationals in connection with the killing of Khalistani terrorist Hardeep Singh Nijjar.\n\nAccording to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP), the arrested members were part of the alleged hit squad that was tasked to assassinate Nijjar in June last year.\n\n\"Today (Friday, May 3) the Integrated Homicide Investigative Team (IHIT) and the Federal Policing Program Pacific Region announced the arrests of three individuals for their alleged involvement in the killing of Hardeep Singh Nijjar on June 18, 2023,\" the RCMP said in a statement.\n\nThe arrested Indian nationals have allegedly played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the parking lot of Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia.\n\nThe Canadian media identified the arrested persons as Kamalpreet Singh, Karanpreet Singh and Karan Brar.\n\nThe police have charged them with first-degree murder and conspiracy in the Nijjar case but the charges have not been tested in the court.\n\nThe three arrested Indians were reportedly living as non-permanent residents in Alberta for three to five years and the police have also released their photographs.\n\nThe murder of the the Khalistani terrorist had become a major flashpoint in the diplomatic relations between India and Canada last year after Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau accused Indian government's hand in it.\n\nTrudeau told the country's Parliament that Ottawa has \"credible allegations\" of the involvement of Indian government agents in Nijjar's killing.\n\nNew Delhi vehemently rejected his allegations, terming them \"absurd\" and \"politically motivated\". India also demanded evidence from Canada to back Trudeau's claim, but they failed to provide none.\n\nIndia also raised the issue of disparity in the Canadian diplomats' strength in India and the alleged violence against Hindus in Canada.\n\nIndia also accused Canada of being a safe haven for Khalistani extremists and demanded action against them.\n\nNijjar, a Canadian citizen, hailed from Indian state of Punjab. He was declared a terrorist by New Delhi and was wanted in the country on various terror charges. {"uri": "8110680391", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "06:04:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T06:04:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T06:03:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.fijitimes.com.fj/canada-police-charge-three-with-murder-of-sikh-leader-nijjar-probe-india-link/", "title": "Canada police charge three with murder of Sikh leader Nijjar, probe India link", "body": "Ottawa (Reuters) -Canadian police on Friday arrested and charged three Indian men with the murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar last year and said they were probing whether the men had ties to the Indian government.\n\nNijjar, 45, was shot dead in June outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population.\n\nA few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police named the three men as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, an RCMP superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nThe Indian mission in Ottawa did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India.\n\nThe presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labeled Nijjar a \"terrorist\".\n\nLast week the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with U.S. law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details, and suggested more detentions might be coming.\n\n\"This investigation does not end here. We are aware that others may have played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to finding and arresting each one of these individuals,\" said assistant RCMP commissioner David Teboul.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday, police said.\n\nThey are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.\n\nTrudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder.\n\nNew Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\n\"We welcome the arrests but this does lead to a lot more questions,\" said Balpreet Singh, legal counsel and spokesperson for the Canada-based World Sikh Organization advocacy group.\n\n\"Those who have been arrested are part of a hit squad but it's clear that they were directed,\" he said by phone.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation.\n\nLast November, U.S. authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder on U.S. soil of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the U.S. and Canada.\n\n\"While today's action ... is a step forward, it only scratches the surface,\" Pannun said in a statement, calling for action to \"dismantle the networks that enable and perpetuate such crimes against Canadians on Canadian soil\".", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8110121819", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:32:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:32:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:32:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/canadian-police-arrest-3-indian-nationals-in-killing-of-khalistan-separatist-nijjar-media-reports-4534824", "title": "Canadian police arrest 3 Indian nationals in killing of Khalistan separatist Nijjar: Media reports", "body": "Ottawa, May 3 (PTI) Canadian police on Friday arrested three Indian nationals believed by investigators to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year, according to media reports.\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" Three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar, CTV News quoted a senior government source as saying.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to commit murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nA report in Global News identified the suspects as Indians nationals.\n\n\"The RCMP took the Indian nationals into custody on Friday morning,\" almost a year after Nijjar was gunned down, the report said.\n\nCiting sources, it said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to commit murder on May 1, 2023 in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023 and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nThe men were arrested Friday during police operations in at least two provinces, the report said.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police are expected to announce the arrests and share some details of their investigation later Friday, CTV News reported, quoting a senior government source.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a \"problem\" and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n\"PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,\" External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n\"This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,\" he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-'Khalistan' slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n\"It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,\" Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its \"core issue\" with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later. "'This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country': PM Trudeau to arrest of 3 Indian men in Nijjar murder case", "body": "Canada is a \"rule-of-law country\" with a strong and independent justice system and a fundamental commitment to protect its citizens, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said, a day after three Indian nationals were charged with the murder of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar.\n\nNijjar, a Canadian citizen, was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton, were charged on May 3 with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Mr. Trudeau said about the arrests at a Toronto gala celebrating Sikh heritage and culture. \"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday,\" Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) quoted Mr. Trudeau as saying.\n\nHe said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing, adding: \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada.\"\n\nDiploamtic tussel\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Mr. Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of 45-year-old Nijjar, a Khalistan separatist. India has dismissed Mr. Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India, which had designated Nijjar a \"terrorist.\"\n\nWill R&AW's overseas operations affect ties? | Explained\n\nAfter three Indian nationals were arrested in connection with the murder, Police in Canada said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\nThe police suggested more arrests might be coming. Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner David Teboul, the force's commander for the Pacific region, said Friday that he wouldn't comment on the alleged links between the three men arrested and Indian officials but noted the force is \"investigating connections to the government of India.\"\n\nMeanwhile, External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar on May 4 said what is happening in poll-bound Canada over the killing of Nijjar is mostly due to their internal politics and has nothing to do with India. He said a section of pro-Khalistan people are using Canada's democracy, creating a lobby and have become a vote bank.\n\nThe ruling party in Canada has no majority in Parliament and some parties depend on pro-Khalistan leaders, he said.\n\nIndia awaiting details about the arrest of three Indians in Canada in Nijjar murder case, says Jaishankar\n\n\"We have convinced them several times not to give visa, legitimacy or political space to such people which is causing problems for them (Canada), for us and also for our relationship,\" Jaishankar said. But the Canadian government has not done anything, he said, adding that India sought the extradition of 25 people, most of whom are pro-Khalistan, but they did not pay any heed.\n\n\"Canada did not give any proof. They do not share any evidence with us in certain cases, police agencies also do not cooperate with us. It is their political compulsion in Canada to blame India. As elections are coming in Canada, they indulge in vote bank politics,\" the minister said.\n\nRead Comments", "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hindu"}, "authors": "Trudeau touts Canada as a 'rule-of-law country' after arrest of 3 Indians in Nijjar murder case", "body": "Toronto: Canada is a \"rule-of-law country\" with a strong and independent justice system and a fundamental commitment to protect its citizens, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said, a day after three Indian nationals were charged with the murder of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar.\n\nNijjar, a Canadian citizen, was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton have been charged on Friday with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Trudeau said about the arrests on Saturday at a Toronto gala celebrating Sikh heritage and culture.\n\n\"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday,\" Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) quoted Trudeau as saying.\n\nHe said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing, adding: \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada.\" The ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of 45-year-old Nijjar, a Khalistan separatist.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India, which had designated Nijjar a \"terrorist.\" After three Indian nationals were arrested in connection with the murder, Police in Canada said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\nThe police suggested more arrests might be coming. Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner David Teboul, the force's commander for the Pacific region, said Friday that he wouldn't comment on the alleged links between the three men arrested and Indian officials but noted the force is \"investigating connections to the government of India.\"\n\nMeanwhile, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Saturday said what is happening in poll-bound Canada over the killing of Nijjar is mostly due to their internal politics and has nothing to do with India.\n\nHe said a section of pro-Khalistan people are using Canada's democracy, creating a lobby and have become a vote bank.\n\nThe ruling party in Canada has no majority in Parliament and some parties depend on pro-Khalistan leaders, he said.\n\n\"We have convinced them several times not to give visa, legitimacy or political space to such people which is causing problems for them (Canada), for us and also for our relationship,\" Jaishankar said.\n\nBut the Canadian government has not done anything, Jaishankar said, adding that India sought the extradition of 25 people, most of whom are pro-Khalistan, but they did not pay any heed.\n\n\"Canada did not give any proof. They do not share any evidence with us in certain cases, police agencies also do not cooperate with us. It is their political compulsion in Canada to blame India. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police named the three men as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karan Brar, 22. The police said they were probing whether the men had ties to the Modi government, Reuters reported.\n\nHere are 10 updates on this big story:\n\nSikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar was shot dead in June outside a Sikh temple in Surrey in 2023.After a few months, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement. Trudeau's remark soared ties between the two countries. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India. Indian authorities in 2020 labelled Nijjar a \"terrorist\".\n\nCanada arrests suspects in killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar\n\nAccording to the Canadian Police, more detentions are on the pipeline. \"This investigation does not end here. We are aware that others may have played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to finding and arresting each one of these individuals,\" Assistant RCMP Commissioner David Teboul told Reuters.Canadian police said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies in apprehending the three men. Last week the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nIndia summons Canadian envoy over 'pro-Khalistan' slogans\n\nThe three Indian men were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday. They are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.Canada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation in connection with Nijjar's murder.Last November, US authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder on US soil of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the US and Canada.\n\nKhalistani terrorist Prabhpreet Singh nabbed at Delhi airport by Punjab Police\n\nLast year, Indian national Nikhil Gupta was charged by federal prosecutors in connection with his involvement in a foiled plot to assassinate Pannun. Gupta has been charged that he was working with an Indian government employee and had agreed to pay an assassin $1,00,000 to kill Pannun.\n\nNijjar killing: Justin Trudeau blames previous Canada govt for 'cosy' India ties\n\nIndia had accused Nijjar of links to terrorism, but angrily denied involvement in the slaying. Indian authorities accused Nijjar of involvement in an alleged attack on a Hindu priest in India and announced a reward of about $16,000 for information leading to his arrest in 2022.Nijjar, an Indian-born citizen of Canada, was a plumber. He was a prominent member of a movement to create an independent Sikh homeland known as Khalistan.\n\nMilestone Alert! {"uri": "8110953613", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "10:24:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T10:24:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T10:23:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://kathmandupost.com/world/2024/05/04/canada-police-charge-three-with-murder-of-sikh-leader-nijjar-probe-india-link", "title": "Canada police charge three with murder of Sikh leader Nijjar, probe India link", "body": "The trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday, police said. They are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.\n\nCanadian police on Friday arrested and charged three Indian men with the murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar last year and said they were probing whether the men had ties to the Indian government.\n\nNijjar, 45, was shot dead in June outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population. A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police named the three men as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, an RCMP superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nThe Indian mission in Ottawa did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labeled Nijjar a \"terrorist\".\n\nLast week the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details, and suggested more detentions might be coming.\n\n\"This investigation does not end here. We are aware that others may have played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to finding and arresting each one of these individuals,\" said assistant RCMP commissioner David Teboul.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday, police said. They are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.\n\nTrudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\n\"We welcome the arrests but this does lead to a lot more questions,\" said Balpreet Singh, legal counsel and spokesperson for the Canada-based World Sikh Organization advocacy group.\n\n\"Those who have been arrested are part of a hit squad but it's clear that they were directed,\" he said by phone.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Last November, US authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder on US soil of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the US and Canada.\n\n\"While today's action ... is a step forward, it only scratches the surface,\" Pannun said in a statement, calling for action to \"dismantle the networks that enable and perpetuate such {"uri": "8114060701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:35:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:35:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:35:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.tamilguardian.com/content/three-arrested-and-charged-over-sikh-activists-killing-canada", "title": "Three arrested and charged over Sikh activist's killing in Canada", "body": "Canadian police on Friday arrested and charged three Indian men with the murder of Sikh activist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar last year and said they were probing whether the men had ties to the Indian government.\n\nNijjar, 45, was shot dead in June outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population. A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited evidence of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi. India's government called the claim \"absurd\" and took steps that led Canada to withdraw more than 41 of its diplomats from the country.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police named the three men as Karanpreet Singh, 28, Kamalpreet Singh, 22 and Karan Brar, 22, all Indian nationals who had been in Canada for between 3 to 5 years.\n\n\"We're investigating their ties, if any, to the Indian government,\" Mandeep Mooker, an RCMP superintendent, told a televised news conference.\n\nThe Indian mission in Ottawa did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India.\n\nLast week the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States.\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday, police said. They are due to arrive in British Columbia by Monday.\n\nTrudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\n\"We welcome the arrests but this does lead to a lot more questions,\" said Balpreet Singh, legal counsel and spokesperson for the Canada-based World Sikh Organization advocacy group.\n\n\"Those who have been arrested are part of a hit squad but it's clear that they were directed,\" he said by phone.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Justin Trudeau After 3 Indians Arrested", "body": "Toronto:\n\nCanada is a \"rule-of-law country\" with a strong and independent justice system and a fundamental commitment to protect its citizens, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said, a day after three Indian nationals were charged with the murder of Khalistani terrorist Hardeep Singh Nijjar.\n\nNijjar, a Canadian citizen, was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton have been charged on Friday with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Trudeau said about the arrests on Saturday at a Toronto gala celebrating Sikh heritage and culture.\n\n\"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday,\" Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) quoted Trudeau as saying.\n\nHe said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing, adding: \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada.\" The ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of 45-year-old Nijjar, a Khalistan separatist.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India, which had designated Nijjar a \"terrorist.\" After three Indian nationals were arrested in connection with the murder, Police in Canada said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\nThe police suggested more arrests might be coming. Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner David Teboul, the force's commander for the Pacific region, said Friday that he wouldn't comment on the alleged links between the three men arrested and Indian officials but noted the force is \"investigating connections to the government of India.\" Meanwhile, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Saturday said what is happening in poll-bound Canada over the killing of Nijjar is mostly due to their internal politics and has nothing to do with India.\n\nHe said a section of pro-Khalistan people are using Canada's democracy, creating a lobby and have become a vote bank.\n\nThe ruling party in Canada has no majority in Parliament and some parties depend on pro-Khalistan leaders, he said.\n\n\"We have convinced them several times not to give visa, legitimacy or political space to such people which is causing problems for them (Canada), for us and also for our relationship,\" Jaishankar said.\n\nBut the Canadian government has not done anything, Jaishankar said, adding that India sought the extradition of 25 people, most of whom are pro-Khalistan, but they did not pay any heed.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\n\"Canada did not give any proof. {"uri": "8110594371", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "04:23:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T04:23:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T04:22:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/world/2024/05/501_374029.html", "title": "Canada arrests 3 over killing of Sikh activist", "body": "Karan Brar, Kamalpreet Singh and Karanpreet Singh, the three individuals charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in relation to the murder in Canada of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar in 2023, are seen in a combination of undated photographs released by the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team (IHIT). Reuters-Yonhap\n\nCanadian police on Friday arrested three men over the killing last year in Vancouver of a Sikh separatist, whose death has been linked to the Indian government.\n\nThe murder of Hardeep Singh Nijjar plunged Canada and India into a serious diplomatic crisis last fall after Prime Minister Justin Trudeau suggested Indian government involvement in the homicide.\n\nIndia dismissed the allegations as \"absurd\" and responded furiously, briefly curbing visas for Canadians and forcing Ottawa to withdraw diplomats.\n\nThree Indian nationals, two aged 22 and one aged 28, were arrested Friday and charged with first degree murder and conspiracy charges. They are accused of being the shooter, driver and lookout on the day Nijjar was killed.\n\nThey were arrested by police in Edmonton, in the neighboring province of Alberta, where they reside, and are being held pending further proceedings.\n\nAll had been in Canada for between three and five years, police said at a news conference.\n\n\"This investigation does not end here. We are aware that others may have played a role in this homicide,\" said Mandeep Mooker of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police's homicide investigations team.\n\nPeople gather at Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara, site of the 2023 murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar, in Surrey, British Columbia, Canada, May 3. Reuters-Yonhap\n\n'Credible allegations'\n\nNijjar -- who immigrated to Canada in 1997 and became a citizen in 2015 -- advocated for a separate Sikh state, known as Khalistan, carved out of India.\n\nHe was wanted by Indian authorities for alleged terrorism and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\nOn June 18, 2023, he was shot dead by masked assailants in the parking lot of the Sikh temple he led in suburban Vancouver.\n\nTrudeau announced several months later that Canada had \"credible allegations\" linking Indian intelligence to the killing and expelled an Indian official, spurring the diplomatic tit-for-tat with New Delhi.\n\nMooker said Canadian police are still investigating the ties of the suspects, \"if any, to the Indian government.\"\n\n\"It is a bit of a sigh of relief that the investigation is moving forward,\" Moninder Singh, a close friend of Nijjar, told AFP.\n\n\"It is ultimately India who is responsible and hiring individuals to assassinate Sikh leaders in foreign countries,\" said Singh, spokesperson for the British Columbia Council of Gurdwaras.\n\nIn November, the U.S. Justice Department charged an Indian citizen living in the Czech Republic with allegedly plotting a similar assassination attempt on American soil.\n\nProsecutors said in unsealed court documents that an Indian government official was also involved in the planning.\n\nThe shock allegations came after U.S. President Joe Biden hosted Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi for a rare state visit, as Washington seeks closer ties with India against China's growing influence.\n\nU.S. intelligence agencies have assessed that the plot on American soil was approved by India's top spy official at the time, Samant Goel, The Washington Post reported this week.\n\nCanada is home to some 770,000 Sikhs, who make up about two percent of the country's population, with a vocal minority calling for an independent state of Khalistan. Nijjar was labeled a terrorist by India.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the death of Nijjar, a Canadian citizen. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as absurd.\n\nCTV and Global News first reported the news of those arrested on Friday, with CTV saying all three were Indian nationals.\n\nNeither the RCMP nor the Indian mission in Ottawa were immediately available for comment.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation.\n\nLast November, U.S. authorities said an Indian government {"uri": "8110145304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:54:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:54:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:54:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/news/report/canadian-police-arrest-3-suspects-in-nijjar-murder-case-media-report/20240504.htm", "title": "Canadian police arrest 3 suspects in Nijjar murder case: Media report", "body": "The Canadian police on Friday arrested three members of an alleged hit squad investigators here believe was tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year, according to a media report.\n\nIMAGE: Designated terrorist Hardeep Singh Nijjar, who was slain in June 2023. Photograph: Courtesy X\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\"\n\nThree people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar, CTV News quoted a senior government source as saying.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to commit murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023 and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nThe men were arrested Friday during police operations in at least two provinces, the report said.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police are expected to announce the arrests and share some details of their investigation later Friday, CTV News reported, quoting a senior government source.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a \"problem\" and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n\"PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,\" External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n\"This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,\" he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-'Khalistan' slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n\"It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,\" Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity.\n\nSubsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its \"core issue\" with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. {"uri": "2024-05-344599971", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "04:26:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T04:26:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T04:26:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.telegraphindia.com/world/canadian-authorities-arrest-three-indian-nationals-in-connection-with-khalistan-separatist-hardeep-singh-nijjars-murder-say-more-involved-in-case/cid/2017591", "title": "Canadian authorities arrest 3 Indian nationals in connection with Nijjar's murder, say more involved in case", "body": "Karan Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals, residing in Edmonton have been charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder\n\nCanadian authorities, who arrested three Indian nationals in connection with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Canada, said their investigation has not concluded and \"others\" played a role in the homicide.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals, residing in Edmonton have been charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\nThe three are believed by investigators to be members of an alleged hit squad tasked by the government of India with the killing of Nijjar, 45, outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\n\"The investigation does not end here. We are aware that there are others out there that played a role in this homicide and we remain dedicated to identifying and arresting each one of them,\" Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, Officer in Charge of the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team (IHIT) said.\n\nThe three men were arrested for the murder of Nijjar Friday morning by IHIT investigators, with the assistance of members from the British Columbia and Alberta Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) and the Edmonton Police Service.\n\nRoyal Canadian Mounted Police Assistant Commissioner David Teboul said they are not able to make any comments about the nature of the evidence collected by police nor \"can we speak about the motive\" behind Nijjar's murder.\n\n\"However, understanding this situation has attracted considerable and very broad public interest, I will say this matter is still very much under active investigation. I will underscore that today's announcements are not a complete account of the investigative work currently underway.\n\n\"There are separate and distinct investigations ongoing into these matters, certainly not limited to the involvement of the people arrested today, and these efforts include investigating connections to the Government of India.\" The ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" Teboul said that three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar.\n\nTeboul stressed that the murder remains \"very much under active investigation.\" During the press conference, Superintendent Mandeep Mooker, who leads the Integrated Homicide Investigation Team, said, \"IHIT is releasing photos of the accused men in hopes of furthering its investigation. Anyone who may have seen these individuals, in or around Surrey, in the weeks leading up to the homicide, or anyone with information about the homicide is asked to contact IHIT.\n\nHe said that the suspects \"were not known to the police\" before the investigation into Nijjar's death, according to reports.\n\nMooker said all three are Indian nationals and have been living as non-permanent residents in Canada for the last three to five years.\n\nHe said coordination with India has been \"challenging and rather difficult for the last several years\".\n\nMooker said that his investigation has relied on the Sikh community's support.\n\n\"We would not be at this point without the bravery and courage of the Sikh community coming forward with information for this investigation,\" he said, adding that he believes they will continue to come forward for any future investigations, according to the report.\n\nCiting sources, a report in Global News said that the suspects had entered Canada on \"student visas but may have been working at the direction of Indian intelligence when they shot Nijjar.\" According to court records, Brar has been charged with a murder that occurred in Surrey on June 18, 2023. He also faces a charge of conspiracy to murder on May 1, 2023, in Edmonton and Surrey, the report said.\n\nTalking to reporters, Canada's Public Safety Minister Dominic Leblanc declined to confirm the Indian government connection, saying such questions are best addressed by the RCMP.\n\n\"I have full confidence in the security apparatus of the government of Canada and the work of the RCMP, and the work that the (Canadian) Security Intelligence Service does,\" Leblanc said.\n\n\"I think the police operation that you see ongoing today confirms that the RCMP take these matters extremely seriously. But questions with respect to particular links or non-links are properly put to the RCMP,\" he added.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023, and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nIndia on Monday summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-Khalistan slogans at the event in the presence of Prime Minister Trudeau and several other leaders.\n\nNijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its \"core issue\" with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended the issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later.", "source": {"uri": "telegraphindia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Nijjar was labeled a \"terrorist\" by India.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder of Nijjar, a Canadian citizen. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as \"absurd.\"\n\nCTV and Global News first reported the news of those arrested yesterday, with CTV saying all three were Indian nationals.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police are due to brief media about the case at 3:30pm EDT (1930 GMT).\n\nNeither the RCMP nor the Indian mission in Ottawa were immediately available for comment.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. {"uri": "8110130607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:41:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:41:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:40:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/hardeep-singh-nijjar-killing-canadian-police-arrest-three-suspects-in-killing-of-khalistan-separatist-says-media-report-5938812.html", "title": "Hardeep Singh Nijjar Killing: Canadian Police Arrest Three Suspects in Killing of Khalistan Separatist, Says Media Report | LatestLY", "body": "Ottawa, May 3: Canadian police on Friday arrested three members of an alleged hit squad investigators here believe was tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year, according to a media report. The ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" Three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar, CTV News quoted a senior government source as saying. Court documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to commit murder in Nijjar's death. Nijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen. Hardeep Singh Nijjar Killing: 'Sikhs for Justice' Calls for Indian Consulate 'Shutdown' in Canada After PM Justin Trudeau Alleges India's Hand in Killing of Pro-Khalistan Leader\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023 and the date of Nijjar's killing. Quoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton. Members of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nThe men were arrested Friday during police operations in at least two provinces, the report said. Sources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police are expected to announce the arrests and share some details of their investigation later Friday, CTV News reported, quoting a senior government source.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence. Trudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters. On the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a \"problem\" and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination. India's Ties With Canada May Have Undergone 'A Tonal Shift' in Recent Days, Says PM Justin Trudeau\n\n\"PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,\" External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing. \"This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,\" he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-'Khalistan' slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges. \"It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,\" Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar. Days after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its \"core issue\" with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country. Following Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. {"uri": "2024-05-345500623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:14:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:14:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:00:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/canada/trudeau-calls-canada-a-rule-of-law-country-after-arrests-in-nijjar-s-murder-case", "title": "Trudeau Calls Canada a 'Rule-of-Law' Country After Three Arrested in Nijjar's Murder Case", "body": "Canadian PM Justin Trudeau at the event where pro-Khalistan slogans were raised. | Image:X@CPAC_TV\n\nNew Delhi: In his first reaction after Canada authorities made the arrests in the murder cade of Hardeep Singh Nijjar, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said that the arrest reflect that Canada is a \"rule-of-law country\". The Canadian Prime Minister said that every Sikh was feeling unsafe after Nijjar's killing. Nijjar headed the Khalistan Tiger Force (KTF) and was wanted by NIA in India. He was killed by unknown assailants in British Colombia last year.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Trudeau said about the arrests on Saturday at a Toronto gala celebrating Sikh heritage and culture. He said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing, adding, \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada.\"\n\n\"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday,\" Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) quoted Trudeau as saying.\n\nPolice Arrests 3 For Nijjar's Killing\n\nCanadian authorities arrested three Indian nationals in connection with the killing of terrorist-designate Hardeep Singh Nijjar. Police arrested - Karan Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28 - all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton. They have been charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) said they are investigating if the Indian government was involved in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia Responds to Canada's Remark\n\nResponding to a question on India-Canada relations after the recent arrests, India's external affairs minister Dr S Jaishankar said that what was happening in Canada was due to its internal vote-bank politics. \"Canada did not give any proof. They do not share any evidence with us in certain cases, police agencies also do not cooperate with us. It is their political compulsion in Canada to blame India. As election is coming in Canada, they indulge in vote bank politics,\" said Dr. Jaishankar.\n\nThe ruling party in Canada has no majority in Parliament and some parties depend on pro-Khalistan leaders, said Dr Jaishankar, adding that a section of pro-Khalistan people are using Canada's democracy, creating a lobby and have become a vote bank.\n\nIndia-Canada Ties Strained After Nijjar's Killing\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of 45-year-old Nijjar. India has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\"\n\nNijjar was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023. Pro-Khalistani leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar, designated as a terrorist in India, was wanted by India's National Investigative Agency.\n\n(With PTI Inputs)", "source": {"uri": "republicworld.com", {"uri": "2024-05-344982025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "14:06:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T14:06:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T14:06:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.streetinsider.com/Reuters/India+waits+for+details+on+arrests+in+Canada+over+Sikh+separatists+murder/23173732.html", "title": "India waits for details on arrests in Canada over Sikh separatist's murder", "body": "Karan Brar, Kamalpreet Singh and Karanpreet Singh, the three individuals charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in relation to the murder in Canada of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar in 2023, are seen in a combination\n\nBHUBANESWAR, India (Reuters) - India will wait for Canadian police to share information on the three Indian men it has arrested and charged with the murder of a Sikh separatist leader last year, Foreign Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar said on Saturday.\n\nCanadian police charged the three on Friday over the murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar and said they were probing whether the suspects had links to the Indian government.\n\nJaishankar said he had seen news of the arrests and said the suspects \"apparently are Indians of some kind of gang background... we'll have to wait for the police to tell us.\"\n\nThe trio, all Indian nationals, were arrested in the city of Edmonton in Alberta on Friday, police said.\n\nNijjar, 45, was shot dead in June outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population. A few months later, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited credible allegations of Indian government involvement, prompting a diplomatic crisis with New Delhi.\n\nNijjar was a Canadian citizen campaigning for the creation of Khalistan, an independent Sikh homeland carved out of India. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi, which had labeled Nijjar a \"terrorist\".\n\nCanadian police said they had worked with U.S. law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details, and suggested more detentions might be coming.\n\n(Reporting by Jatindra Dash; Writing by Arpan Chaturvedi; Editing by Ros Russell)", "source": {"uri": "streetinsider.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "StreetInsider.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sikhs"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separatism", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Separatism"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murder", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Murder"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "India"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "India"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Canada"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Canada"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karan_Brar", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Karan Brar"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conspiracy_theory", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Conspiracy theory"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuters", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Reuters"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhubaneswar", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Bhubaneswar"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Bhubaneswar"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "India"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S._Jaishankar", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "S. {"uri": "8110088598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "18:03:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T18:03:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T18:02:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/canadian-police-arrest-3-suspects-in-killing-of-khalistan-separatist-nijjar-media-report-4534752", "title": "Canadian police arrest 3 suspects in killing of Khalistan separatist Nijjar: Media report", "body": "Ottawa, May 3 (PTI) Canadian police on Friday arrested three members of an alleged hit squad investigators here believe was tasked by the government of India with the killing of Khalistan separatist Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey last year, according to a media report.\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of Nijjar.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" Three people have been arrested and charged in the killing of Sikh activist Nijjar, CTV News quoted a senior government source as saying.\n\nCourt documents show Karanpreet Singh, Kamalpreet Singh and Karan Brar are each facing one count first-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to commit murder in Nijjar's death.\n\nNijjar, 45, was gunned down outside his gurdwara in Surrey, B.C., on June 18, 2023. He was a Canadian citizen.\n\nThe indictments Friday allege the conspiracy unfolded in both Surrey and Edmonton between May 1, 2023 and the date of Nijjar's killing.\n\nQuoting sources close to the investigation, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reported that the police are actively investigating possible links to three additional murders in Canada, including the shooting death of an 11-year-old boy in Edmonton.\n\nMembers of the hit squad are alleged to have played different roles as shooters, drivers and spotters on the day Nijjar was killed at the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara in Surrey in British Columbia, according to the sources.\n\nThe men were arrested Friday during police operations in at least two provinces, the report said.\n\nSources said investigators identified the alleged hit squad members in Canada some months ago and have been keeping them under tight surveillance.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police are expected to announce the arrests and share some details of their investigation later Friday, CTV News reported, quoting a senior government source.\n\nIndia had on Thursday rejected fresh comments by Prime Minister Trudeau on the killing of Nijjar and said the remarks once again illustrated the political space given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence.\n\nTrudeau addressed a Khalsa Day event in Toronto on Sunday that was attended by some pro-Khalistan supporters.\n\nOn the sidelines of the event, he told the media that the killing of Nijjar in British Columbia in June last year created a \"problem\" and that he cannot ignore it, in an apparent reference to his earlier allegations of involvement of Indian agents in the assassination.\n\n\"PM Trudeau has made such remarks earlier as well. His remarks illustrate once again the political space that has been given in Canada to separatism, extremism, and violence,\" External Affairs Ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal said in New Delhi at his weekly media briefing.\n\n\"This not only impacts India-Canada relations but also encourages a climate of violence and criminality in Canada to the detriment of its own citizens,\" he said when asked about Trudeau's remarks.\n\nIndia on Monday also summoned the Canadian deputy high commissioner and lodged a strong protest with him over the raising of pro-'Khalistan' slogans at the event in the presence of Trudeau and several other leaders. Nijjar was a Khalistani separatist and he was wanted in India on various terror charges.\n\n\"It is a problem in our relations with India because we cannot ignore that,\" Trudeau said on the killing of Nijjar.\n\nDays after Trudeau's allegations, India asked Ottawa to downsize its diplomatic presence in the country to ensure parity. Subsequently, Canada withdrew 41 diplomats and their family members from India.\n\nIndia has been asserting that its \"core issue\" with Canada remained that of the space given to separatists, terrorists and anti-India elements in that country.\n\nFollowing Trudeau's allegations last year, India temporarily suspended issuance of visas to Canadian citizens. The visa services were resumed several weeks later. On June 18, 2023, Nijjar, a Canadian citizen, was shot and killed outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia. \"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Trudeau said about the arrests on Saturday, May 4.\n\nKaran Brar, Kamalpreet Singh and Karanpreet Singh residing in Edmonton are among the three Indian nationals being charged with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder on Friday, May 3.\n\nCanadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) quoted Trudeau, \"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday.\" He said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing. \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada,\" he added.\n\nAfter three Indian nationals were arrested in connection with the murder, Police in Canada said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details. The police suggested more arrests might be coming.\n\nDavid Teboul, Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) Assistant Commissioner, the force's commander for the Pacific region, said on Friday that he wouldn't comment on the alleged links between the three men arrested and Indian officials but noted the force is \"investigating connections to the government of India.\"\n\nIndia reacts\n\nFurther to this, India has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\" The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India, which had designated Nijjar a \"terrorist.\"\n\nMeanwhile, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Saturday said that what is happening in poll-bound Canada over the killing of Nijjar is due to their internal politics and has nothing to do with India. He said a section of pro-Khalistan people are using Canada's democracy, creating a lobby and have become a vote bank. \"We have convinced them several times not to give visa, legitimacy or political space to such people which is causing problems for them (Canada), for us and also for our relationship,\" Jaishankar said.\n\nJaishankar further added that the Canadian government has not done anything and India sought the extradition of 25 people, most of whom are pro-Khalistan, but they did not pay any heed. \"Canada did not give any proof. They do not share any evidence with us in certain cases, police agencies also do not cooperate with us. It is their political compulsion in Canada to blame India. was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023.\n\nKaranpreet Singh (28), Kamalpreet Singh (22) and Karan Brar (22), all residing in Edmonton, Alberta, were taken into custody on Friday.\n\nFollowing the three arrests, police in Canada said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a Last November, U.S. authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the U.S. and Canada.\n\nCanadian police charged three people on Friday with the murder of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar in the province of British Columbia in June 2023, Canadian media said, citing court documents. Nijjar, 45, was shot dead outside a Sikh temple in Surrey, a Vancouver suburb with a large Sikh population.\n\nThe news broke days after the White House expressed concern about the reported role of the Indian intelligence service in assassination plots in Canada and the United States. The presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated New Delhi. Nijjar was labeled a \"terrorist\" by India.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau announced in September that Canadian authorities were pursuing allegations linking Indian government agents to the murder of Nijjar, a Canadian citizen. New Delhi rejected Trudeau's claim as \"absurd.\" CTV and Global News first reported the news of those arrested on Friday, with CTV saying all three were Indian nationals.\n\nThe Royal Canadian Mounted Police are due to brief media about the case at 3:30 p.m. EDT (1930 GMT). Neither the RCMP nor the Indian mission in Ottawa were immediately available for comment.\n\nCanada had been pressing India to cooperate in its investigation. Last November, U.S. authorities said an Indian government official had directed the plot in the attempted murder of Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, a Sikh separatist and dual citizen of the U.S. and Canada. Canadian Public Safety Minister Dominic LeBlanc, in charge of Canadian law enforcement agencies, did not directly confirm the arrests but told reporters the probe into Nijjar's murder was \"still an active police operation\".\n\nThe Canadian Broadcasting Corporation earlier cited a source saying investigators had identified the suspects in Canada some months ago and had been keeping them under "title": "PM Trudeau touts Canada as a 'rule-of-law country' after arrest of three Indians in Nijjar murder case", "body": "Nijjar, a Canadian citizen, was shot dead outside a gurdwara in Surrey, British Columbia, on June 18, 2023.\n\nKaran Brar, 22, Kamalpreet Singh, 22, and Karanpreet Singh, 28, all Indian nationals residing in Edmonton have been charged on Friday with first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder.\n\n\"This is important because Canada is a rule-of-law country with a strong and independent justice system, as well as a fundamental commitment to protecting all its citizens,\" Trudeau said about the arrests on Saturday at a Toronto gala celebrating Sikh heritage and culture.\n\n\"As the RCMP stated, the investigation remains ongoing, as does a separate and distinct investigation not limited to the involvement of the three people arrested yesterday,\" Canadian Broadcasting Corporation quoted Trudeau as saying.\n\nHe said that many in Canada's Sikh community are feeling unsafe following Nijjar's killing, adding: \"Every Canadian has the fundamental right to live safely and free from discrimination and threats of violence in Canada.\"\n\nThe ties between India and Canada came under severe strain following Trudeau's allegations in September last year of the \"potential\" involvement of Indian agents in the killing of 45-year-old Nijjar, a Khalistan separatist.\n\nIndia has dismissed Trudeau's charges as \"absurd\" and \"motivated.\"\n\nThe presence of Sikh separatist groups in Canada has long frustrated India, which had designated Nijjar a \"terrorist.\"\n\nAfter three Indian nationals were arrested in connection with the murder, Police in Canada said they had worked with US law enforcement agencies, without giving additional details.\n\nThe police suggested more arrests might be coming. Royal Canadian Mounted Police Assistant Commissioner David Teboul, the force's commander for the Pacific region, said Friday that he wouldn't comment on the alleged links between the three men arrested and Indian officials but noted the force is \"investigating connections to the government of India.\"\n\nMeanwhile, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Saturday said what is happening in poll-bound Canada over the killing of Nijjar is mostly due to their internal politics and has nothing to do with India.\n\nHe said a section of pro-Khalistan people are using Canada's democracy, creating a lobby and have become a vote bank.\n\nThe ruling party in Canada has no majority in Parliament and some parties depend on pro-Khalistan leaders, he said.\n\n\"We have convinced them several times not to give visa, legitimacy or political space to such people which is causing problems for them , for us and also for our relationship,\" Jaishankar said.\n\nBut the Canadian government has not done anything, Jaishankar said, adding that India sought the extradition of 25 people, most of whom are pro-Khalistan, but they did not pay any heed.\n\n\"Canada did not give any proof. They do not share any evidence with us in certain cases, police agencies also do not cooperate with us. It is their political compulsion in Canada to blame India. As elections are coming in Canada, they indulge in vote bank politics,\" the minister said.", "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hindustan Times"}, "authors": [],
